topic_or_construct: Perceived likelihood of winning a prize in scratch card games
justification: The paper uses this scale to measure participants' perceived likelihood of winning a prize while playing Power 5, ranging from 1 (Extremely unlikely) to 7 (Extremely likely). This instrument is used to assess how the icon array presentation affects gambling perceptions.

topic_or_construct: Excitement to play scratch card games
measured_by: 7-point scale ranging from 1 (Not at all excited) to 7 (Extremely excited)
justification: Participants rated their excitement to play Power 5 on this scale. The scale evaluates the impact of information presentation on gamblers' excitement levels.

topic_or_construct: Urge to gamble on scratch card games
measured_by: 7-point scale ranging from 1 (No urge to gamble) to 7 (Strong urge to gamble)
justification: This scale measures participants' urge to gamble on Power 5, demonstrating the effect of graphical vs. non-graphical information formats on gambling desire.
The PGSI, a subscale of the Canadian Problem Gambling Index, measures problem gambling symptomatology, providing a reliable and valid assessment of gambling-related harms.
The CRT evaluates participants' ability to suppress intuitive but incorrect responses in favor of deliberative correct answers, assessing their cognitive style in gambling scenarios.
This scale assesses participants' ability to understand and properly use numerical information, which is important in perceiving gambling odds and making gambling decisions.

measured_by: Scale ranging from 1 (Have not played) to 6 (Played 24 or more times)
justification: The scale measures participants' self-reported scratch card gambling frequency in the past 12 months, helping to understand how gambling behavior correlates with various constructs.
